column4: coz: I have two 512GB hard drives set up as a RAID0, I have Windows 7 installed and try to install Ubuntu 11.04 alongside with Windows 7
real raid or fakeraid?
I guess it's a fake raid, set up through the BIOS
then afaik you can't grub can only handle raid1.
Ubuntu 10.10 Worked perfectly with the same configuration
is the ubuntu partition on raid0 too?
Yes.  I tried upgrading 10.10 to 11.04 : Same error.  Clean install over 10.10 : Same error.  Clean install alongside Windows 7 after having deleted Ubuntu 10.10 : Same error
ok, anything else than raid1+grub is new to me :) -- sorry
When I've made the RAID, I made it as a RAID0
I can't understand why Ubuntu 10.10 works PERFECTLY and not Ubuntu 11.04...

can't help you there. I can't understand why/how and since when grub does other stuff than raid1 especially if that is a fakeraid where the disks are exposed. I usually have either real raid where I can't even get to the disks or do raid1 (to be honest I'm afraid of raid0)
: I know almost nothing about RAIDs, is it possible for me to make a real RAID ?
sure if you are willing to spend the money (usuall that starts at a few hundred bucks)
as for raid0: 0 is for the amount of data you can restore if any single one of the involved disks fail

Hm... Well, I guess I'll have either to stay on Ubuntu 10.10, find what's wrong with Ubuntu 11.04, or clean up my computer and use one of my 512GB hard drives for Windows 7 and the other one for Ubuntu...  But my Windows stuff needs at leat 750GB =/
would be an option. Personally I don't quite get why I always need the latest version. I think back at home there's still some box running 9.something :)
what is the actual error you are seeing? (I don't have it in my backlog)
The actual error is "Executing grub-install/dev/sda failed       This is a fatal error"
I tried to install the bootloader on the RAID itself like I did with Ubuntu 10.10, but Ubuntu 11.04 ALWAYS tries to install it on /dev/sda, what ever I tell it to do.
I think that is what 10.10 did too. may be a new bug in grub. behind the scenes IIRC grub just installs to each disk involved in a raid even if you give it the raid device
If I let the bootloader install itself on /dev/sda with Ubuntu 10.10 my computer doesn't boot on anything, but if I tell it to go on isw_something, it boots GRUB
Is there a possibility to upgrade from Ubuntu 10.10 to Ubuntu 11.04 WITHOUT touching GRUB ?
you could pin the package, but I don't know it offhand. just google for apt-pinning
